messages.subject: Re: [UnschoolingDiscussion] food and emotional well-being (was peace and love)
messages.msgSnippet: I don t know if most people experience this, but I get very cranky if I m hungry. Especially if I don t realize that I m hungry. So in my experience food is
messages.messageBody:
I don't know if most people experience this, but I get very cranky if
I'm hungry. Especially if I don't realize that I'm hungry. So in my
experience food is inextricably linked to emotional well being and it
has nothing to do with an eating disorder. My younger sister is the same
way. When she was little (7?) and I was in my early 20s we went to a
museum and she was acting very emotional and I wasn't sure why. Then she
had a banana and everything smoothed out. She just hadn't eaten enough
at lunch.

Of course it is not healthy to eat to deal with any and all emotions.
Sometimes you have to employ other solutions. Those people who think
food is the solution to everything have clearly gone too far.

-Vijay


On Friday, August 6, 2004, at 11:59 PM, Dianne wrote:

> And why make a big connection between food and
> emotional well being.
> Isn't that kind of connection between food and
> emotions what causes people with eating disorders to
> eat in order to feel better.� Food feeds our bodies.
> I try to avoid certain things because of what I
> believe (and many others believe) to be unhealthy for
> my body.� Food does taste good and a lot of people
> (including me) enjoy food and there is nothing wrong
> with that, but I don't equate food with my emotional
> well being.
>
>
>
>
>
>
> =====
> Dianne in Tacoma, WA
> Well behaved women don't make history.
>
>
